title: Supporting Content Provision in Environmental Information Infrastructures

author: Sven Schade, Joint Research Centre, European Commission

segmentation: So basically I want to present some work which I did together with Laura Diaz from the University of Co Metal in Castillon in Spain and it's a joint work of ours.
We did there JFC while she was visiting as a scientist for three months and this contributes a little bit to a project called the Euro Geoss, which is not exactly in the.

In the same objectives as the other projects, overseas and Big Workshop, it's more project on streamlining European Voice Studios and they did some work there and this was in the context and we submitted this paper to this workshop because it gives a bit different view than all the other presentations so far because we do not deal with using the content but how to support actually different experts to push their content.
Into an environmental information infrastructure and as we were told to have very short talks like 11:50.
Minutes I said OK, I'll start with the conclusion because this is what you should should take home from this presentation.
Actually, we say that the deployment of content into an environmental information infrastructure is the main bottle bottleneck in sharing environmental information.
This is really the core issues.
To make this data available in the infrastructure not using it afterwards.
We worked on a solution which we now turn to your Geo service factory.

And this deployment actually remains very challenging if you just deploy data like a shapefile or a map in the system.
It's relatively easy and straightforward, and this is what we currently have in our prototype, but it's much more challenging to deploy models and model descriptions into these infrastructures.

Also, the model Web concept which was mentioned already yesterday in the answer web is following these ideas.

Usually if you look at an environmental information, infrastructure or geospatial information infrastructure, yeah, situation where you have an end user searching, viewing, downloading, exploiting data and then provider on the other side doing deployment of services and registering content.
You actually want to do is to take this registration.
And deployment and move it also to the end user.
So if you as a user created a new product you should be able to push it into the information infrastructure to make it available to others.
And this pushing means deploying this new information but also registering it in terms of meta data.
And in my talk, I would focus on the deployment.
As I said of environmental models and not of can't.

And if you look at the classical architecture of environmental information infrastructure, we have these basically three layers.
What is the core content which you're dealing with?
Then you have something like networking.

Do spatial networking services which provide you all these discovery functionality, viewer, download processing and then you have an application layer which usually has a workflow engine doing the composition in some application logic and then also a service connector.
Which basically enables communication with the application and the service.

It is dash error here to push content.
From the applications into the infrastructure so the baby is also this service collector to push content via the service factory in data services, marketing services, processing services and so on.
And if we now look at the environment.
Models this basically means if you want to deploy a model this should be done or could be done by a processing services.
So to make it available as a new processing service for training or.
Or anything else, and the registration is basically recording method data that you need to deploy at the Discovery service.
So what we propose just as a first take on this idea, is to have four different ways of deploying models into information infrastructures.
The first one is actually not dealing really with the.
Employment it SMS registration.
So what you could do is you could describe as a core process of the model using a workflow modeling language.
It doesn't have to be executable, is just for a major data purpose.
To understand the model better and you can register this into a catalog and make make it able for people to explore this workflow behind the model.
One of the benefits would be.

You can use the output because you get information about the history of self and how it was created.
A big challenge in this is that we have known for most mentioned so far in the model semantics, so we need an approach to describe what these models are really about.
And the vocabulary to describe environmental models is very dependent on the domain, so we have to see how we can improve this.
Situation.
